laws.summary: Virginia enforces reasonable non-compete agreements under common law. Non-competes must protect legitimate business interests and be reasonable in scope, duration (typically 1-2 years), and geography. Virginia courts will modify overly broad agreements to make them reasonable (blue pencil doctrine). Generally employer-friendly on non-competes.
laws.notes: Virginia is generally employer-friendly on non-competes but prohibits them for low-wage workers. Federal FTC ban blocked in 2024.
laws.law_citation: Common law; Va. Code § 40.1-28.7:7 (low-wage worker restriction)
laws.full_text:
Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, customer relationships)
Must be reasonable in duration (typically 1-2 years maximum)
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must be reasonable in scope of prohibited activities
Must be supported by adequate consideration
Virginia courts will blue-pencil (modify) unreasonable provisions
LOW-WAGE WORKERS: Cannot enforce non-competes for employees earning less than median wage
Low-wage restriction: Va. Code § 40.1-28.7:7 prohibits non-competes for workers earning less than median wage for Virginia or their locality
Exception: Sale of business non-competes still enforceable
Courts balance employer interests with employee mobility
Non-solicitation agreements generally easier to enforce than full non-competes
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia non-compete requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia has NO statewide salary history ban. However, state agencies are prohibited from asking about salary history under executive directive. Private employers may ask about and consider salary history. Richmond and other localities may have local restrictions.
laws.notes: Virginia has not enacted statewide salary history ban for private employers. Only state government agencies restricted.
laws.law_citation: Executive Directive 6 (2019) for state agencies; No statewide private employer statute
laws.full_text:
STATE AGENCIES: Cannot ask about salary history (Executive Directive 6)
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: No restriction on asking salary history
Private employers may ask applicants about prior compensation
Private employers may use salary history in setting compensation
Some localities may have local restrictions
Federal equal pay laws still apply
Many employers voluntarily avoid asking for equity reasons
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia salary history requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia PROPOSED pay transparency legislation (SB 1132 in 2024) but it was VETOED by the governor. As of January 2026, Virginia has NO pay transparency law requiring salary ranges in job postings. Employers are not required to disclose compensation ranges.
laws.notes: Virginia proposed but did not enact pay transparency law. Governor vetoed SB 1132 in 2024.
laws.full_text:
STATEWIDE: No requirement to include salary ranges in job postings
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to applicants
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to current employees
STATEWIDE: No pay data reporting requirements
SB 1132 was vetoed in March 2024
Federal equal pay laws still apply
Employers may voluntarily disclose pay ranges
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia pay transparency requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia has limited ban-the-box protections. State agencies cannot ask about criminal history on initial applications. Private employers generally can ask about criminal history at any stage but must comply with federal FCRA. Richmond has local ban-the-box ordinance.
laws.notes: Virginia is employer-friendly with minimal state restrictions. Federal FCRA provides primary regulation.
laws.law_citation: Va. Code § 2.2-2817.2 (state agencies); Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681); Richmond ordinance for city contractors
laws.full_text:
STATE AGENCIES: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial application
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Generally can ask about criminal history on applications
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Must comply with federal FCRA
RICHMOND: City contractors subject to ban-the-box ordinance
FCRA: Must get written consent before background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action notice with copy of report
FCRA: Must provide final adverse action notice
FCRA: Seven-year lookback for most non-conviction records
FCRA: Ten-year lookback for bankruptcies
FCRA: No time limit on convictions
FCRA: $75,000+ salary positions exempt from lookback limits
Must consider: nature of crime, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
Cannot discriminate based solely on arrest without conviction
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia background checks requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia has NO statewide paid sick leave or paid leave mandate for private employers. No state law requires employers to provide paid or unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA. Employers may voluntarily offer paid leave benefits.
laws.notes: Virginia has no paid leave mandates. One of more employer-friendly states on leave policies.
laws.law_citation: No Virginia statute; Federal FMLA (29 U.S.C. § 2601)
laws.full_text:
STATEWIDE: No requirement for paid sick leave
STATEWIDE: No requirement for unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA
Private employers not required to provide sick leave benefits
Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees: up to 12 weeks unpaid leave
FMLA requirements: employee worked 1,250 hours in past 12 months, employed 12+ months, employer has 50+ employees within 75 miles
Employers may establish own sick leave policies
No state penalties for lack of paid leave
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia paid leave requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia generally enforces arbitration agreements under federal and state law. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Virginia has enacted Uniform Arbitration Act. Agreements must be clear, mutual, and not unconscionable. Courts favor arbitration.
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: Virginia is arbitration-friendly. Courts enforce valid arbitration agreements.
laws.law_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); Va. Code § 8.01-577 et seq. (Uniform Arbitration Act)
laws.full_text:
Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA and Virginia Uniform Arbitration Act
Must be in writing and signed by both parties
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Adequate consideration required
Virginia courts favor arbitration
Class action waivers generally enforceable
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable
Can be challenged on contract grounds (fraud, duress, unconscionability)
Federal policy favoring arbitration applies
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia arbitration requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate employment at any time for any legal reason or no reason. Exceptions exist for discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of contract. Virginia is generally employer-friendly.
laws.notes: Virginia is at-will employment state with typical exceptions. Generally employer-friendly. Handbook disclaimers recommended.
laws.law_citation: Common law doctrine; Va. Code § 2.2-3900 et seq. (Virginia Human Rights Act - anti-discrimination)
laws.full_text:
Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid by next regular payday
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, national origin, sex, pregnancy, childbirth, age, marital status, disability, genetic information (Virginia Human Rights Act)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (workers' comp claim, jury duty, military service, National Guard duty)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy (refusing to violate law)
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract (written or implied)
Employment handbooks may create implied contracts if not properly disclaimed
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
Virginia courts narrowly construe at-will exceptions
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia at will employment requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Virginia has NO state statute restricting private employer drug testing. Employers may conduct pre-employment, random, reasonable suspicion, and post-accident testing. Recommended to have written policy. Workers' compensation benefits may be affected by positive drug tests.
laws.notes: Virginia is very employer-friendly on drug testing with no state restrictions. Drug testing significantly impacts workers' comp claims.
laws.law_citation: Va. Code § 65.2-306 (workers' comp drug testing provisions); No general restriction statute
laws.full_text:
STATEWIDE: No restriction on private employer drug testing
Pre-employment testing: Permitted
Random testing: Permitted
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted
Post-accident testing: Permitted
Workers' comp: Positive drug test creates rebuttable presumption that intoxication was sole proximate cause of injury
Workers' comp: Employee must rebut presumption to receive benefits
Workers' comp: Test must be conducted within 12 hours of accident
Recommended: Written drug testing policy applied consistently
Federal DOT requirements apply to transportation/safety-sensitive positions
No state protections for medical or recreational marijuana users (marijuana illegal in Virginia for non-medical use)
Medical marijuana: Limited program exists but no workplace protections
laws.suggestion: Review Virginia drug screening requirements and ensure compliance.
